The class is poorly organized overall. No questions are allowed during tests, so if you're not sure what a question is asking, you aren't allowed to ask for clarification. Michelle is a good lecturer. Class notes are required and podcasts for every lecture are posted on Carmen. Pretty easy class except for the confusing wording of questions.

I did not understand the lectures about 50% of the time, but he seems like he wants to help. He usually asked for questions after each slide. The HWs and exams were fair but some questions felt like curveballs. The strat for this class: read the textbook reading in the syllabus before lecture days. This helps makes understanding lectures more easy

Very arrogant and not eager to help. Will give you smart a- answers and refuses to provide a study guide. Not passionate about teaching other than "read textbook". You're better off not going to class and learning from the textbook. His accent makes class lectures hard to understand.  Attendance not required and neither is his teaching.

All of his slides are itemized and he FLIES by problems. I ended up taking pictures on my phone and copying it down later. The most painful class I have taken. Dude is so lucky stats is a semi-self explanatory class because NO ONE would have passed if it was genuinely hard. He also sits and waits for someone to answer his questions no matter what

The worst TA I've ever met. Slow and rough reply for email. Most strict, stubborn, rigid, I would say if you can take stat in-person, don't choose online or you'll regret when you meet this guy. Bad at all.
Boring lectures, mumbles pretty often, but he's a good guy
Boring
I'm sure Keith is a nice guy but he is just a terrible lecturer. Save your time and watch Deborah's lectures online and even that probably won't help so stick to teaching yourself through Youtube.
Not a good lecturer, hard to understand and not good at speaking to a crowd. Just use Dr. Rumsey's online lecturers which are shorter and more clear. The class was pretty easy as well.

Even though it's a standardized course, he managed to be the most boring lecturer I've ever had. Half the time, we didn't even get through all the material on the weekly quiz. Ended up not going and watching Rumsey's online podcasts, which saved a lot of time. Definitely recommend doing her online class for this instead of Rodgers.

Dr. Rodgers quite literally is the most boring lecturer ever. He asks questions and sits in silence till someone answers even if it is a hard topic and no one truly knows. He seems like a nice person but I learned all of the work from Chegg and YouTube not him.
Keith is the most boring lecturer ever. I almost fell asleep several times during his class. He just reads off the power point the entire class. I learned everything in the class from my TA.

This was a difficult class, and Prof. Rogers wasn't helpful. In the lectures, he would go on and on about things that had nothing to do with math. The lectures consisted of him asking a question and staying silent until someone knew it. I swear half of the class time was wasted like that. Unless you are good at teaching yourself, don't pick him.

Keith is very odd. His lectures are boring, so it was hard to stay awake. Content is super easy so it makes up for how dry his lectures are. Do the homework and have a basic understanding of the material and you will get an A. Therefore, I would try to get a different professor if possible to hopefully make it somewhat interesting for you.

This was one of the easiest classes I have ever taken. But, Keith was dry, boring, and weird. He read off the powerpoint slides. He would ask for participation and wait until he got it. Exams and homework are easy so you will do fine with him as your professor. But, if you have the option to take someone else I would for your own sanity.

I have never had a more boring professor than Keith. I only went to lecturers to socialize with my friend and for TopHat; his lectures are horrible and he is not good at explaining things, I taught myself everything. He also likes to interrupt you and not answer your questions directly. With that being said, if you put the effort in youll do fine.

Only gave him a 2 because you can't help but feel bad for the poor guy. As many have already said, you'll learn much much more from recitation/your TA. The only reason to go to class would be to get the extra credit questions and fill in the notes maybe. I'd recommend taking another professor, honestly.

This class was the easiest class that I ever taken. The homework can be a little tough, but most of the answers come straight from the lecture notes that are given to you. A sheet of notes was allowed to be used on the midterm and final exam, so you really don't have to study for them at all. This class seriously was so easy.

Keith is a very interesting professor. Get ready for awkward classes (he asks a question and will wait for a response no matter how long it takes). I was only really able to pass this class with Stattutors which is a tool available on sapling when you sign up for it in this course because going to class isnt just enough to pass.

Keith is a straight savage. Really bad at lecturing and really boring but the class isn't hard. He will wait 10 min for you to answer and if you answer wrong expect to be interrupted with a "wELL nO" He has a weird accent too. Sometimes shows up late but expects you to wait for him. Only reason I did well was bc of my TA.

Wicked nice guy but the class was beyond boring. Fell asleep multiple times, you can tell her loves stats but doesn't have the right teaching technique. The material was extremely easy and no one should have any issue passing the class as long as you show up.

Keith wasn't that good at lecturing and that's all that professors do in STAT1350. I had this class in the morning and almost fell asleep because I was so bored all the time. The material is bland and so was the way it was taught. He's a nice guy though. As long as you do your homework and study, you can get an A or a B.

Weird accent (semi-british?) makes it sometimes hard to understand him during lecture. Very interactive style of lecture, which may or may not work. When he asks a question in lecture, he expects an answer, even if it takes 5 minutes for someone to come up with it. When giving an answer, speak loudly and confidently.

Awesome instructor. He is very intelligent and fair grader. Lecture can move quickly at times, so if you need one on one guidance just ask! It's really not that difficult. If anything was wrong with this class, it was the students not taking it seriously. So don't be a jerk in class and pay attention. You will learn a lot.

Keith was clear with his material and was even willing to teach topics out of the syllabus. He made things pretty clear and made sure we understood concepts clearly. Very helpful and is even ready to help students outside class.

Keith is such a good guy and he means well, but hes such a bad lecturer. i came out of lecture more confused than when i came in. and when we would ask for clarification, we didnt get it. not only this, but he constantly let us out late. his notes are illegible. going to recitation is the only way that i am passing this class. 0/10 lecturer
Class was pretty hard, but Patrick was a good lecturer and gave lots of examples.

He was a super good lecturer and very funny. The exams were 80% of the final grade, but he made sure to hold a lot of review sessions and his office hours were very helpful. Exams were a lot harder than expected, but he did curve them a tiny bit. Hard class, but great professor.

Class is difficult with tough heavily weighted midterms. Lots of online homework and quizzes that are generally fairly simple. His lectures are very detailed with entertaining examples. He does midterm and final review sessions and definitely cares a lot about the class. It would be an amazing class if the exams were just 10-15% easier.

He was truly such a nice person and honestly so funny. His lecture notes were very very detailed and explained almost everything. He was always offering help if needed, and the HW wasn't that bad to do. The exams were kinda hard though- a lot of material and you really needed to understand it. You did have a note sheet that saves you on the exams.
Patrick is a great professor that clearly explains everything. To do well in his class you simply have to be able to solve the examples he goes over in lecture.

The tests were unreasonably weighted and it was impossible to get your grade back after a bad midterm. There was no extra credit and lots of homework/quizzes. I went to his office hours very often and always thought I understood the material. He is down-to-earth and humorous, but the structure of the class needs to change. It is far too difficult.

Dr. Kelbick is lucky that her material is relatively easy to understand because if I only listened to her teaching I would have failed the class. The only way to learn her material is through practice problems because her regurgitation of the textbook makes it clear that even she doesn't understand the material.

i took this course online. we never had to go to class even though we had a meeting time. the only time we met is for exams which are proctored through zoom (cam and mic on). she makes sooo many mistakes on practice questions and even on exams. grading is easy though and hw and lab quizzes are unlimited attempts. i had to rush on exams bc of time

She seems entirely unprepared every single lecture, and looks at the slides as if it's her first time seeing them. She cancelled the first ever class we had, and assigned us lecture videos to watch instead. She doesn't publish any exams from previous semesters to help you prepare. You're better off skipping lecture and watching youtube videos.
Very scattered and all over the place. Forgets to mention subject matter. Trails off a lot and does not explain things well at all. Youtube will be your best friend if you have her.

Take this class online!!!! If you're reading this and you already scheduled, go back and fix it. In my opinion, Dr. Kelbick is a very nice person, but not the best lecturer. Her online classes are easier to stay focused on. I ended up just going back and listening to lectures because I couldn't stay focused in class.

Professor Kelbick is passionate about what she does, but her monotone voice makes it nearly impossible to stay focused on what is being talked about. Attendance begins to dwindle during the second/third week of the semester, and most of the students are watching the lecture videos instead of going to class. Even so, the tone is still draining.

Professor Nicole is a genuinely good professor who truly cares about her students. Even during her office hours, she reaches out and answers everything in the lab, explaining concepts clearly. If you watch her lecture videos, you will simply excel in her course. If I ever take a statistics class, I want her to be the professor.

Dr. Kelbick's stats 2480 class was extremely straightforward, which I appreciated. She also clearly cares about students, was flexible with deadlines, and was easy to talk to. There are frequently mistakes in her slides presentations. Her lectures aren't captivating to most, but statistics can tend to be a dry subject anyway.

Professor Kelbick was an okay professor. For me, the material was not interesting at all and I found it difficult to pay attention to her lectures. She does well in helping individual people with the class. To prepare for exams, just look over the slides and you should be good. Many problems seem difficult, but can be solved easily using the TI-84.

Coming from someone who is unbias, I thought Kelbick was an overall solid class. Her exams were not too hard and the other grades were easy to obtain. Her lectures were very boring, but the class material was not overly complicated. If you review the slides and know how to do the practice problems, you will be good.
VERY GOOD

Professor Kelbick is a lecturer who cares about her students. She gives feedback on difficult hw problems and explains them to the entire class. Her lectures are more boring but were super helpful for tips and tricks. I would definitely use the textbook as a supplement.
Extremely disorganized and boring lectures. Prof was very confusing and I ended up using the textbook to learn the material, rather than her notes. Would avoid her class if possible.

Her lectures are useless if you're not paying her attention to her rambling and very boring regurgitation of the material from the textbook. I stopped going to lectures a quarter of the way through the semester and I ended up doing better not relying on her slides and instead relying on the textbook. Read the textbook if you end up taking her!

professor kelbick is a kind and accessible professor, but lectures are very boring and non-informative. all tests and quizzes are open note so just prepare good notes and you'll be okay. she doesn't mind giving extensions on assignments if you really need it

Had her for Stats lecture 2x a week. I only went for the first month. Her class is a snooze fest and I learned more from the TA who was more informative and entertaining. A few times she got so angry about not being ale to connect her computer- she let us leave at the start of class. Fairly easy class- just super boring if Stats isn't your forte.

Girlfriend is actually bonkers. I swear everything she says she doesn't think about before hand. Seriously only passed this class because I took statistic in high school. If you can seriously avoid this women. The frustration she causes is NOT worth it.

Dr. Kelbick is a sweet and understanding person, but it is impossible to stay focused during her lectures. There is a lack of cohesion from topic to topic, and her monotone voice will put you to sleep. However, she is an easy grader and can be persuaded to add points to a test grade if your argument is good enough. Read the book!!

Prof Kelbick is extremely nice and you can tell she genuinely cares about her student's success- she's always there to help. BUT- she is just not a good teacher. Took her for 5301, 90% of the class just stopped going to lecture and taught themselves the material with the book. Unorganized/dry lectures, but content is 100% doable-just teach yourself

Professor Kelbick can be a little scatterbrained at times, but the course material is easy enough that it can still be learned during the lecture. Recitation is more helpful than lecture. Kelbick is a nice person, just not a great lecturer. She spends a lot of time going over practice problems that don't require that much attention.

If you take her, prepare to teach yourself everything in this class. She really does not teach the students, rather she runs SAS code and then mumbles a bit and moves onto something else. She needs to explain what and why the code is written a certain way, and have more organized lectures. Total waste of time. She needs to make improvements.

Relatively easy, gets more difficult after the midterm. Nicole's lectures were pretty scattered and don't keep your attention. You can get extra credit for going to class thru TopHat (up to 10 points). I found recitation to be more helpful than lectures. Highly recommend printing the exam practice problems and reviewing that to study.
I personally loved Nicole and thought she was a great professor. Easiest math class Ive ever had.
Hard course with no curve. The professor is not caring in general.
She is amazing, and better than other as a personal opinion. I love her class and I Would recommend her. SHE CARES

For a 5000-level class, this class was easy af. If you've ever taken AP stats or a entry level stats class you'll be fine. Nicole is nice but highly unorganized. Also, she is incapable of captivating anyone. Her lectures are scattered and move very slowly. Very quick to lose your attention. Homeworks use R. Exams are what you'd expect
Extremely easy class. I barely showed up the entire semester. She may be unorganized in class but extremely helpful during office hours.

Lectures were poor. Prof. Kelbick was often unprepared and would often do examples incorrectly or pause for a few minutes to read the textbook. She did seem to care, so I felt bad for her that she struggled during lectures. Exams were fairly simple and only required basic knowledge of statistics.

This was one of the easiest classes I have ever taken. She was pretty unorganized and taught very slow. Going to class was unnecessary because all the notes were posted online. Don't bother going to her office hours cause she doesn't go either.

Professor Kelbick may not be the most organized professor but she cares about her students and is very nice. If you took stats in high school, this class won't be very hard. If you try in this class you can get an A. If you don't do well on one of the midterms but you do well on the final and homework she will boost your grade.
She is super nice, generous, very helpful and considerate.

She is really nice and wants her class to learn. That being said, the class moves extremely slowly. I didn't see any new material all semester -- it was all high school level (or even lower). The homework and tests are very easy. I was hoping for derivations and mathematical rigor, but the class was far too simple and basic for that.

Professor Kelbick is one of the nicest professors you will meet, but I do not think she is especially good at teaching.  She often gets confused by questions asked and ends up answering them incorrectly.  I use the Mark Risser's lectures to help me learn (they are all on YouTube) because he is a better teacher. Tests are easy (have extra credit).

So, she's not spectacular. That said, she's definitely not the worst option. And she's definitely one of the nicest profs I've had, she was always willing to work with students on due dates. She's not the best lecturer but she did get better as the semester went on. Take her over Bach, but be prepared to put in some work outside of class.

Dr. Kelbick just returned from a 10 year hiatus raising her kids to teach again.  She was still adjusting to academic life and that's totally understandable.  She was very accessible outside of class and gave very very fair tests.  I ended up with a 97 on the final exam despite struggling in the beginning of the semester.  I would recommend.

Nicole is incredible caring and understanding. Although it did take her some time to get into the swing of things, her tests were very straightforward. Mark risser's videos help a ton for the exams. homeworks weren't too bad. Overall, nicole is a good/easy option for stats 3470.

She isn't an amazing lecturer, but she isn't that bad, and it doesn't matter because Mark Risser's videos on YouTube explain everything in the class perfectly.  She is super caring about her students and takes their feedback to heart.  The tests were very straightforward. I would highly recommend taking her for this class. 1000x better than Bach.
Does not teach reads the slides that are basically copied from textbook

I'll be honest, she is not a good teacher.  HOWEVER, her tests are SUPER easy if you know what you are doing. You get a cheat sheet for every exam, and she offers up to 12% extra credit. If you have taken stats before then you might consider taking this just for an easy A. Just don't plan on actually learning anything.

She cant explain everything clear in class. However, her slices posted online are really helpful. Please please please read them. U can pass the test. The average is fine but she said she will curve the class grade. U can take cheat sheet in each exam which make the class more competitive.

Usually comes to class disorganized and spends 10mins of class preparing. She puts up a text doc onscreen (no slides) and scrolls through it while she talks. For lack of a better way of saying it she doesn't explain ANYTHING. She shows an equation and then a word problem and jumps straight to answers with no in-between steps.  I advise you avoid.
Not worth it
lowww taper fade XD

I enjoyed Prof. Blevins class very much. The class isn't that challenging, but it is also not an easy A. You do have to make sure that you come to every class as she takes a grade on attendance, but usually she puts the lecture notes online as well. All quizzes and Exams were open note, but she was often a tricky grader.
Nicholas was great! His lectures were amazing and much clearer than Dr. Rumsey.
Best professor I ever had

Nick is a TA not a professor, but he is the greatest TA I have ever had. If I did not have him as my recitation leader I would not be doing this well in stats 1430. His explanations are better than Dr. Rumsey's. Also for exams it is very conceptual not a lot of calculations at all. Do not study the recitations study the slides she gives.

What you need to know about Professor Jones' class is that she doesn't teach it. It's 99% taught by her TA with the 1% being pre-exam study sessions she hosts. Professor Jones' is very nice but I literally learn nothing in her class because her TA's just talk AT you instead of teaching. You will need to teach yourself all of the material.

Relatively easy class if you put in some effort. Basic math that you barely even have to do b/c of the ti-84 stat function. Lots of extra credit assignments.

The 2 exams will make or break your grade, do not neglect studying for those.

Professor was super nice and easy to reach out to. Very understanding with deadlines if you had valid excuse.

This is your only option for stats. People that aren't good at math will more than likely fail. You can't get help at the math lab. How this class is ran as an online class is stressful. So many teachers and TA's.
She conveyed material by just talking it through to herself without explaining it to students. Your grade almost solely relies on your exam performance.

Relatively easy online course. Learn to use stat functions on a calculator, it's so much easier than calculating by hand. Long lectures and around a 15-question homework due almost every Friday with unlimited attempts. Recitation attendance is required. Use your TAs.

Professor Jones is not as terrible as people try to paint her. She does give tons of HW, quizzes, and her exams are often harder than the questions we practice. Her lecture videos are little to no help so I often looked for outside resources to teach me. My advice if you take her stats class is to utilize her office hours! Overall decent

Not sure whether there are any other professors teaching this online during the summer but if so, please take this course with them. The TA told us duing our last reciation that prof. Jones would curve our grade but she didn't. The class average 58.5% and I'm sure barely ayone actually passed her class.

I took this as a virtual class because that was the only option. It contained lots of homework, quizzes, and tests. The tests were very hard with averages being 60% and 59% on a midterm and a final and she refused to curve which was very disappointing. It was very hard for an entry-level STATs class.

This class is a 3 credit hour class, however I spent a lot of time outside of class trying to understand the material. The lectures were straighforward, however the exams were a lot harder. There are homeworks every week and are typically hard and take a long time to complete. Overall, this class was difficult for a intro level stats class.
She makes simple things extremely complicated.

This was not a bad class at all. I do have to say though, since class was online, you had to copy notes from an pre-made lecture that was sometimes hard to follow. The tests being online were very tricky because the only way to get points was to write out each step taken to get the answer to the problem. There is a couple extra credit options!

I really likes Professor Jones. She was caring towards her students, however with the Stats department there wasn't much she could do. This online class was very hard. The exams are worth 65% of your grade, even though HW and Quizzes are worth more point wise, it won't help you that much. I got A's on all HW and Quizzes and failed all exams. C-

This course was good! Ive never been super great at math, but this course was a do it at your own pace". I found this to be really helpful. There were lots of PowerPoints, but they weren't too bad. Any questions that I had were quickly answered by both Jones and the TAs in a way that made it easier to understand. I would definitely recommend!

I absolutely hate stats, science, math, really any class with numbers. Considering that, Laura was great. The course definitely makes you work for it and it is A LOT of reading PowerPoint slides. However, the TAs are always available and Laura responds very fast. Everyone is very understanding and genuinely wanted you to do well.
I took this class online so the lectures were pre-recorded and uploaded - it was easy to fall behind! but Prof. Jones was so nice and helpful during the office hours

Online class, posted powerpoints with audio attached. Clear lectures, but lots of little assignments to keep track of. Easy class if you need it as a GE or a prerequisite, definitely doable online. TAs are very accessible. But actually pay attention and do homework, exams are worth a big portion of the grade.
Professor Blackburn, JD. is a wise elder, but this course is difficult and boring.
Its not a good choice. Take it somewhere else!
She is very boring .

She made me doubt about myself whether I'm good at statistics, and made me nearly give up. However, I even did better in the advanced statistics course, which proves that it's not my fault and it's her fault.
Do not choose it!
It course is so tm difficult!
Although she is not a professor, she is a good lecturer. She is young and simple, but not naive. She often shares her life experience. I really like her.
She is moderate, which is not excellent but not bad. I commented here before but my comment was deleted by this website. This is 21th century! How could this be happened? !

Laura is my favorite professor that I ever met in this university. Her lecture is so systematical and you just need to listen and take note of her good blackboard writing notes and do the review. She also have extra credit for someone who points out her mistakes in class.

She is an enthusiastic lecturer. She really cares about the material and how the students perform. While she doesn't just hand you points, she definitely provides a lot of information on how one can do well in the class. I'm glad I won't have to take another stats class, but I wouldn't mind taking more if she were the instructor.

Laura is hands down the best professor I've had in college. I'm taking her course as a retake and can finally understand the material because of her clear lectures and help. She genuinely wants to make sure students understand the material. HIGHLY recommend

Makes statistics as interesting as it could be. He is charismatic, kind, and cares a lot about his students. Explains difficult concepts very clearly and in detail. Homework and exams are tricky but exams are curved.

Professor MacEachern knows his stuff and more importantly he cares about his students. I felt he was very available. He can be disorganized - it is especially challenging when there is no textbook to fall back on.
MacEachern made quality control way more interesting than expected.

Lectures are confusing -- goes fast and assumes you remember everything from 3201. Lots of test/assignment questions are all or nothing. Accessible outside of class, but going to office hours didn't really help, was sort of condescending. His saving grace is that there is very little HW, and the exams are very similar to the practice exams.

His average is about 50, and it's very tough. He doesn't provide adequate information, and it's heavily self-motivated in terms of looking for resources. If you are in his session, don't hesitate, run as fast as possible.

Professor Sadeghkhani was a very kind professor, who was empathetic to students. He was always willing to help with grading and answer questions about homework and quizzes. Although he may not have had the most clear lectures, he was normally happy to answer questions. The class was graded primarily by midterms and homework, which were few.

Lectures were boring and difficult to engage with, it was also unclear which material was important for exams or future lectures. However, he provides plenty of review materials and practice questions for the exams which were helpful. If you are capable of learning/understanding material by yourself, you will probably do well enough in this class.

This class is based on 5 HWs and 3 exams, so every point matters. Most exams rely on just using the correct formula that he gives in lectures. His lectures are good and make it clear to know which formulas to use when, and I felt that I understood a great deal from his teaching. His practice material is also good, which helps to reinforce learning
Denied extra test time to disabled students.

REVIEW FOR 3202: Assumes everything is common sense. Talks a bunch but doesn't write down anything on the board. I also got screwed over with a grade and he wouldn't change it even after I pointed out the mistake.

3202 REVIEW! - Leaving review early for people scheduling next semester - avoid if you can. Smart guy but thinks everything is common sense. Goes very fast with minimal explanation, basically just does example problems whole lecture. Assumes you remember EVERYTHING from 3201. Accessible outside of class, but going to office hours didn't help at all
Did not learn anything at all. Asked him at the beginning of the semester about the success rate in his class, and he said it more more than normal for half the class to fail his class.
Nice professor. Really enjoyed taking his class. After following his notes and suggestions, I passed the exam with a B+. Always nice with everyone and his office hours were useful.
He was well organized and explained the materials quite well. His exams were a bit hard but at the end of the semester you feel you have learned something!

Awful. He did not explain lectures well at all. He claimed that he made the easiest midterm of his life which had an average of 14/25. The homework doesn't help your understanding much at all. I only got an A because I watched youtube videos from previous engineering stats professors who actually taught the material.

I genuinely don't understand why anyone's giving this guy good reviews; he's one of the worst professors I've had. His lecture notes are so unorganized and hardly legible. I went to all the lectures and still had to teach myself everything prior to exams. Just be sure you have really good cheat sheets for the exams and you'll be fine in this class.

His teaching is not that direct and you have to study yourself. However, do not bother if you don't understand some stuff because what matters is just the formula and how to use it. If you don't understand the derivation, don't sweat it because you will only need the derived one. His homework is like not abundant and you can enjoy your weekend.

Dropped the class at the recommendation of my advisor because the professor refused to accommodate my disability. The lectures I went to before dropping were hard to follow and he often made mistakes. Midterm averages ended up being around 50%, so I'm not sure I would have passed anyway.
Always available to help and caring about his students. Exams are hard, but if you follow his lectures you can make it.

I am in shock there are any positive reviews from other students. This is the worst professor I have ever had. I understand this is a difficult class overall, but our exam averages have been 50-60 percent, with tough grading. Lectures and example problems are messy and mistake-ridden. In my experience unhelpful outside of class. Avoid at all costs.

This is an extremely difficult and unreasonably stressful class. It is only a 3 credit hour course and I end up studying for it more than any of my other classes. There is no reason for it to be this hard.

I like his teaching style. He uses his iPad and he fills out the notes in the class and he posts the annotations. 
He's standards are a bit high, but sometimes the graders of the course are harsh. He takes care of each his student. You'll love statistics ( maybe lol) after this course.
Responsive and nice.
(Review for STAT 3470) Avoid this professor! Lectures are confusing and messy, midterms contain material not covered in class, and he refuses to accommodate students with disabilities.
STAT 3470. I like his teaching skills. He is keen and responsive. Highly recommend taking this course with him.

This review is actually for STATS 3470 but the class doesn't show up so it is under this class. But anyways, he is a pretty awful professor for STATS 3470. He goes through the content without explaining very well, doesn't answer questions well, is very boring, and gets a lot of examples wrong in class. If you don't have to take this class, DON'T.
Excellent!!!

The group project is graded generously, which is nice for a STEM course. Exams feel pretty difficult but I suspect he curved our final & maybe Midterm 2. He always provides practice exams, which is really nice. Sometimes he goes faster than you can write, but he posts annotated notes after lecture. If you pay attention in class you should do fine.

She sometimes did NOT teach clearly, simply, and effectively. However, she does want you to learn. Also, she is extremely good at clarifying any questions you have. The HWs and exams (exam questions similar to HW and lectures) were fair BUT can be brutal. Overall, she really does care about you and she will improve at teaching as time goes on.

I took Dr. Paganin's course during her first semester as a professor at OSU, and she was incredible. The lectures are easy to follow along with, and taking notes in class is important. The homeworks were very fair, and so is the amount of work she assigns. Exams were very reasonable and nothing on the exams was out of nowhere. 10/10!

Chill dude, really passionate about statistics. Our class was kinda dead cause it was online but he tried to make it interesting as much as he could. HWs and quizzes were relatively easy, they followed the examples from lectures. Attendance wasn't mandatory, and he recorded every lecture so you could go back and rewatch.
Mr. Hilbert is a really nice person, and he is always very kind with the assignments and tests. He is very patient with questions.
little homework, easy exam, kind teacher

He doesn't seem to be fazed with "dumb" questions and he wants you to learn. One lecture, he talked about how in the real world job, grades do not matter since people wont care if you were a straight A student or not, and someone younger will always be better than you. Me and everyone else have to realize its just about the learning, not the grades

had him for 3301, but my experience with him for 3303 was better. Funny, giving generous curve on exams which were not hard to begin with, best part is he was willing to switch the exams to online format because we asked for it. Lectures were pretty slow-paced, contents start off easy with bayes theorem, and gradually gets harder, but still doable
Linear Regression is not an easy class. Thought I was gonna fail but his office hour saved me. He is genuinely willing to help students.

Good prof, the lectures seem pretty textbook and boring but enough to get the point across and get a good passing grade. Just do the homeworks well. The midterms and final exams were open note so you can look over some of your stuff. Project was easy as well. Overall good class, nothing too hard.
Seems like a nice guy, lectures were kinda boring, but the homework was really similar to what we did in class and the exams were fair.
He's really nice. I think he's good at teaching but I was bored most of the time. He was very helpful during office hours and his exams aren't too difficult.
Overall pretty solid instructor. Lectures were clear albeit dry. Exams were tough but they followed the practice problems well and there ended up being a very nice curve at the end of the semester
Boring. Unenthused. Doesn't help students, nor does he really teach the material. would not recommend to anyone.
Class itself wasn't too bad but him teaching the material was basically a waste of time. Learned everything from online videos, book and tutoring center.
Okay class. Nothing special.
Go to class and you will be fine. she is super nice and wants you to truly learn. Gives quizzes and exams but is super easy. Labs are long but bearable.

Show up to class and you'll do fine. The quizzes and tests are not difficult. She is a fair grader and does not assign much homework. She gives you time in class to finish it. The labs are the longest... but not terrible. I would recommend this course.

Never responds email. Unhelpful recitation by a TA. A lot of recitation paper to solve and homework online separately for only 3 credits hours. Online textbook sucks and does not allow round error. Never tell you recitation grade till the end of semester. Just avoid it. Definitely okay for DA students not to take it to pre-study stat and prob.
Baker is a humorous professor, but sometimes his lectures can be difficult to comprehend. The slides are not very helpful and may cause confusion. However, overall, he is a great professor.

No grading transparency. Random grades in the gradebook that were not reflected in the syllabus. Horrible lecture style, seems like he doesn't know his own content. Exams are easy, but he will tank your grades with all the random grades he decides to put in just for sh**s and giggles.

Disorganized and unclear about grading, due dates, and the setup of the entire class. Uses online third party source for his exams which aren't too bad but are harder than his own written exams that he used in the past, which also had partial credit. Only redeeming factor is the extra credit offered, but is also unclear about that.

He was an enthusiastic and fun professor with little homework, but things were not always clearly explained. You definitely have to be proactive in learning and practicing outside of class because of the light work load. All exams are online and open note, and lectures are available via zoom.

The content was a bit disorganized in comparison to the textbook, HW, and Quizzes, but Baker had great lectures. Very funny, respectable guy. Doesn't teach you formulae by hand, but how to compute them online and in TI-84; very efficient. Accommodating for students who wanted to be online for class. Accessible if you email him and ask for help.

Dr. Baker was a funny guy, but his lectures were not helpful and disorganized.  If you don't do well on something it really hurts your grade.  Always answer the tophat question because that is apart of your attendance grade. Recitations were not helpful. Dr. Baker goes off topic and the notes were never helpful for me.
The class was kinda hard, and Dr. Baker wasnt very accessible outside of class which made learning very hard. Chegg carried me through this class.
lecture is just awful, fast speed and no explanation of everything. Quiz are not difficult, but the grading system of quiz is just tough.

Yes, the class is pretty disorganized, but as long as you keep track of what's going on and keep up learning with the textbook in advance before the lectures since he goes insanely fast, you will do fine, expect to use a lot of calculator/Crunchit, but that's the good part, little to no math on your part, and I love Dr.Baker for his personality

The 1 star is for personality. Dr. Bakers funny but his lectures are impossible to follow, I passed the AP Stats test and still felt lost. Hes quick to give accommodations but beware because he NEVER answers email. Had to contact the director a month after he told me I could make up a test because he never answered my 27 emails or zoom messages.

At the end of the semester he admitted to doing worse than usual, so maybe in other semesters he will be more on top of the class, but this one was so stressfully disorganized. Luckily he was forgiving with grades because of it. You never know what assignments are due when, the lectures are missing a bunch of stuff, and it was just so stressful.

Dr. Baker is so disorganized and does not care to ever answer any students emails. He also does not answer the TAs emails. His lectures are confusing and the examples do not make much sense with the material. Hes a nice guy but hes a horrible professor.

He won't ever respond to your emails. He doesn't even respond to TAs emails from what it sounds like. He may have potentially been more busy this semester but he is still a professor at the end of the day and his performance was sub-par. The class material was thankfully easy since most things could just be plugged into the calculator.

Most disorganized professor I have ever had. He never responded to emails and never changed my quiz grade that the online homework portal messed up from week 4 of the semester. Inaccessible to both students and TAs. Go to class for attendance, but you are better off learning from Khan Academy.
Will not respond to his emails no matter what. Teaches his lectures too quickly and is impossible to keep up with.

He's a very funny and entertaining person, and you can tell he truly wants to engage his students. However, he is incredibly disorganized and if you are taking his class online, you will sometimes struggle to get your question answered or be able to fill in all the notes.

I took his online class and as lots of people have already said he is a personable and funny guy. His exams are pretty fair as they pretty much cover the same things in the weekly hw and quiz. At times the online class is a bit disorganized but nothing too bad for me.

Dr Baker is very cool and down to earth. He knows the stuff and knows how to treat his students. His exams are not too difficult. He gives opportunity for extra credits. I'll recommend him taking him especially for any STATS class

Offered abundant chances for extra credit throughout semester. Gave a fair amount of assignments but never too much. Exams were provided through course learning software (Sapling) but were not too hard. Really cares for each and every student. Wants to see students earn good grades. Very accommodating as well. An excellent and knowledgeable prof.
Dr. Baker is very hilarious when teaching Stats. If you stay up with the material this class is not that bad.

Dr. Baker is comedic. He makes statistics personable and relatable, making lots of jokes. Everything else about this class was a joke, too. The midterm/final are difficult, comprising 70% of the grade. His poor articulation in lecture means you should develop a relationship with your TA as soon as possible. No curve but slight grade scale change.

He is better one on one than he is in person. Go to his office hours outside of class. he skips a lot of material in lecture and doesn't stay focused. His tests are fair and if you use the study guide it will aid you preparing for the test.

A funny guy. Good at teaching stats too and tries to make stats relatable to students with sports and current event examples. He'll really help you out if you go to office hours. Only complaint is the final is worth 30% of your grade you really have to rock it out the whole time. Can't just get to an A early in the semester and relax.

Awful professor. It got so bad that 30 students went to report him but nothing happened because he is the head of the department. We had our first midterm well after the point to drop without petitioning and it took him 16 days to grade it. The class ends next week, and I have no idea how I am doing.
He is a good statistics professor. I think he is good at business statistics.
He is a good statistics professor. He is an interesting elder.
Dr. Baker is hilarious. Hes a very personable guy and homework is very light. Exams are a breeze and he wants his students to get good grades.
I did not think he was a bad teacher, but the things he taught us and the homework and quizzes we took every week on Sapling were different, so that made it hard.

I heard great things about Dr. Baker, but they didn't really show through on the online class. He was often late in posting the week's materials, sometimes waiting until Thursday (when the homework is due Friday). At the in-person exams, I could see he was funny just like everyone said, but unfortunately, I didn't really love his online section.

Dr. Baker was a great professor! Even for someone who doesn't like math, he made his lectures easy to follow and engaging. The class is very clearly laid out for you: no surprises- just 1 homework and 1 quiz per week and a few midterms!
Dr. Baker's lectures could be confusing, with lots of examples. But that's how math can be. The tests were very fair and you could definitely get an A in this class.

I didn't do well in 1450, but mostly because it was easy for me to get lost in his "steps for success." He does outline how to solve problems in lecture in a lot of detail, but I found that his steps were more than necessary. If you just learn how to do the homework well (don't use google) every week and do his practice exams, you'll be fine.

Dr. Baker definitely makes learning statistics better, with his humor and engagement with the people in the class. He is interested in getting to know students and ensuring that they succeed. Attendance definitely has a decent impact on your grade, and his practice exams, in my experience have been helpful when  preparing for the test.

Dr Baker was AMAZING. Math in the middle of the afternoon was not my idea of a good time. But he made this class so enjoyable. He even danced to "Juju on that Beat" on stage for us. This was my second time taking Stats (1st at a different school) and I am so glad he was my professor for it. Definitely recommend him!

Dr. Baker is one of my favorite professors. He is very funny and always willing to help. He holds office hours right before his lectures and exams. GO TO THEM. He will drop extremely obvious hints about what will and will not be on the exam.

Amazing professor and very easy class. More than willing to help you if you need it and his tests are extremely fair if you're going through lecture, homework, recitation, and quizzes. Only missed about 10 points in the whole class. I suggest taking this class in person if you have no statistics background and/or are not self-motivated.
Funny guy but wouldn't recommend if you want to actually learn the content. He isn't the best at explaining concepts.

Dr. Baker is so hilarious, and even came to lecture on Halloween in a costume. Uses TopHat to take attendance, which is graded. He is a really great professor, and is always willing to help during his office hours. Provides you with old exams that are very similar in content to the exams you take. He was great to learn from. Would highly recommend.

I have taken Cal 1, math 1172, linear algebra and passed with an A. However, this course is very difficult. I strongly believe it is because Dr Baker isn't the best professor. He is funny but that doesn't help me honestly. His tests are very difficult. The study guide he provides suck. Don't rely on them like I did. Probably gonna fail unless curve

I enjoyed taking Stats with Dr. Baker. He's funny and laid back (he even did a lecture in costume during halloween.) The lectures were straightforward and all the slides were available online, though he regularly took attendance via TopHat in class. The exams weren't difficult. He was a flexible grader.

I really enjoyed Dr. Baker's teaching style, though I recognize it may not be the best for everyone. Because everything builds on everything else, it is important to have good attendance, otherwise the brief explanations he gives in class might get lost in the shuffle. Funniest professor I've had, and very willing to help with questions.

Dr. Baker is incredibly nice and has the jokes, but his class requires some effort.  There's online homework and quizzes which aren't necessarily hard, but his tests can be difficult.  Takes attendance every class.  Very nice professor, but expect to spend some time on the material to get an alright grade.

Dr. Baker is nice guy but not great lecturer because he is not very clear about his explanation and skipping steps made it more difficult to follow. His exams are relatively hard and long for the amount of time given. Not recommended unless you have good statistic background!

Dr. Baker is a great guy, outside of the classroom. His teaching style is very laid back, to the point where it almost isn't teaching at all. He just goes through a powerpoint and students follow along in the notes, but he's never clear on what he's doing or how he got answers. Very difficult to learn from.

I had him for an online class so I never actually talked to him, but he seemed nice enough in his videos.  He did tend to drag on a bit on easy concepts. The only problem I had was that he constantly changed the dates of assignments and with an online class I wasn't checking daily to see if he had changed the due date once again.

Dr. Baker does not explain the concepts well as statistics is a whole different set of concepts than what most people have seen before. He is a nice professor but is not very good at explaining the content.  He goes through a slideshow with the solutions worked out but doesn't explain where each # comes from or why he solved it in that way.

Dr. Baker is a genuine teacher that will listen and try to be as flexible as possible and he also understands that outside factors play in a student's life also. Stats not really my thing but he made the class interesting. You may get called on in class to respond and you should be able to do so and give the reason why.

His lectures were interesting because he liked to joke around, and he keeps you involved by using a software called Tophat to answer questions about lecture that he used for attendance purposes.  But statistics just is not an easy subject unless you are good at math.  I thought the tests were okay, but I am a math minor.

In the beginning, the class was common sense. Later on, it got tough because I did not take it seriously. When I did take it seriously, it actually was easy. Everything builds upon each other, so you have to keep up. Dr. Baker is awesome and so are his lectures. If you see him in his office hours, he breaks down the stats real nicely.

Dr. Baker is a great guy, but this class certainly wasn't easy. As the semester went on, concepts seemed to become more and more unclear and they all built off of each other. All I can say is practice on your own more than just the mandatory homework and go for help before you get too deep and it's too late. Also slightly curved.

I never actually dealt with Dr. Baker, only his TA, but the class is definitely doable. The midterms are easy, the final is a bit harder. There might be a tiny curve which is good. There's homework every week where you get 2 attempts at each problem and then there's a quiz which isn't too bad. I would recommend his class.

Baker is truely a great guy. In a lecture of 400-500 kids he tried to get to know and memorize names. Has notes that you print out and bring to class and just fill in the blanks. He often makes reference to Drake and Migos which is funny. He doesnt really believe in extra credit and midterms are okay but the finals tricky.

Dr. Zhang's lectures are a bit disorganized and often go into proofs more than the main ideas, and most of the class often don't follow him. Interestingly his exams are extremely easy compared to the practice exams and homework, and the homework is also shorter compared to the other STAT 3201 classes.

Dr. Zhang is a very intelligent professor. I think he thinks that he can teach at his own pace and everyone in the class understands it. The homeworks take forever to do and don't really help clarify anything. His exams are extremely difficult. the average for exam 2 was a 42 + final was not much better. curves a ton but not sure if ready for 4202

Prof. Zhang is a really nice guy who I can tell genuinely loves Statistics and wants his students to learn. The class has an intimidating amount of proofs and intense calculus in the homework and notes, a little less in the exams, which gave me a decent amount of anxiety. However, it is all balanced by the heavy curves and lowly weighted homework.

He curves like crazy, which I know makes people want to take this class. However, he has to curve, since his averages are so low. Lecture & homework are all theory, proofs, and needless calc that arent replicated on the exam. The only thing the exam has in common with the lecture is ridiculous calculus. Got a good grade, but not worth the headache.
He is a great professor with many example problems for you to learn. Most important ishe curves a lot on exams.
best statistics professor ever

Dr. Craigmile's lectures are great. He's a bit hyperactive, which makes the class way more interesting. His notes are pretty clear and going to class helps tremendously. Be prepared for him to go SUPER fast, though. He says to students, "I write my exams so I wouldn't get a perfect score." You have to work REALLY hard, but it's worth it!
Pretty nice guy has really cool Irish accent. Go to class pay attention and do the HW and you'll do really well in this class.
watch out for very hard homework and even harder exams
Very good teacher. Very enthusiastic and dedicated. Also, very helpful. He gives very clear examples and explanations.

The class was a lot of work, but *great* instructor. Very organized, *excellent* notes, responsive to questions. Lectures were engaging and entertaining. Be warned that he wanders (physically) a lot; sit in the back if you want to keep him in view! Cool Scottish accent, too.
Loved Dr K, lectures were videos posted and the class times were only used for exams. All exams were open note and she does review videos. Labs were not very helpful but were a nice grade booster.

Stats sucks but Dr. Kubatko makes it a little better. I was often confused as her lectures are very fast, but her office hours do wonders. If deciding between 2450 and 2480 take 2450 because they have recitation to go over topics and not lab. In lab you use R-studio which if you are not doing anything with statistics later in college is useless.

Dr. K is a great teacher. She is so passionate about statistics and attempts to make you love it too. She sometimes messes up problems halfway through but its hilarious when she does. She's super funny and relatable. One homework assignment a week. Quizzes easy and midterms not bad. She says final is formally cumulative but its not cumulative.

Kubatko is a very nice professor with clear lectures. She is approachable and always in a good mood. Class isn't too bad, I thought it was more trouble than it was worth but probably due to my focus being on other courses that semester. Exams were pretty easy and it was always clear what would be on/covered on the exam. Can't go wrong with her

She is an amazing professor! She was very clear on class content and the tested material. She is a very busy lady, but is happy to meet with students outside of class if you email her. The homework affects your grade more than you think so keep using multiple attempts until you get a perfect. The book is also pretty helpful if you need more help.

Lectures were very clear and straightforward in terms of the material and what would be tested on quizzes and exams. She's very eager to help and is eager to answer questions in class and outside of class (through email or office hours. Very kind and wants her students to succeed.

Laura is an amazing professor. She is super nice and very easy to get along with. She cares about her students. She is very busy, but if you want to meet her outside of class, she will try her best to squeeze time out of her busy schedule for you.

Dr. K is a great professor. She is so kind, and her lectures are extremely helpful. She does a great job of answering any questions. The material can be kind of tricky, but she explains everything thoroughly. I would definitely take her class again. Virtually no homework, three quizzes, two midterms, and a final exam.

Dr. K is an incredible lecturer - I feel like she moved at a really good pace, had excellent explanations, was very responsive to questions inside and outside of the classroom. The material can be kind of tough at times but every exam / quiz was very fair. Ask questions. Notes posted online but they only make sense if you go to lecture.

Class is stat for the life sciences (she's also in the EEOB dept). I was worried about the calc portion of the class, but thankfully it's never tested. 2 quizzes, 2 exams with cheatsheets. She's a very good lecturer with great handwriting, and the hw are very helpful. Study/practice from those and it's fully possible to get a 100% in this class.
DO NOT take this class with this professor. She can't teach. She doesn't give examples of how to do the problems she gives in the exams.

For what it's worth, the lectures are okay-ish, but they're not the best as it focuses too heavy on theory versus application. I often had to rely on lectures found on YouTube from the same class. Exams are definitely fair, so watching the lectures is a must. Although there are 200 people to a section, I do wish midterm grades would come in faster.

Professor does not show up to her scheduled office hours, tests are not undergraduate level she specifically says, on week 10 of a 14-week semester, and still don't have any grades. Who knows if I have an A+ or a F!
Good luck getting her to respond... 

I guess I'm just paying to be able to say I'm in Statistics class...
doesnt respond to anyones emails. doesnt give out practice exams.

For 3470, she seemed to really care about her subject material and her students, but was not great at conveying information in a meaningful way. The voice issues were a serious problem to the class, and the lectures were not very helpful. The high ratings on this page are almost certainly smurf accounts, no way around it. Hard class, but doable.

I took online summer Stats 3470 (not 3201) with Professor Cleymaet--her first time teaching it. It was disorganized and the lectures were not always engaging or clear. Her getting covid did not help. Nonetheless, the class was manageable. Homework was straightforward and 30% of the grade. We had 48 hours to do all three exams and could use notes.

The other reviews earlier don't match up to how professor Cleymaet is currently. I've received multiple extensions to homework and a lot of slack from the professor. During her lectures she sticks to the material that will be given on tests and homework so that students will be prepared and know exactly what to do for every question.

This class was substantially better than I expected when I took it online over the summer. Olivia was a great instructor (although her vocal injury and COVID-19 infection were disruptive to the course), extremely understanding, knowledgeable, & caring. If I had taken this course during the year w/ a different instructor, it would have been bad.

Actually terrible. I took AP Stats in high school and passed the exam, but she takes stuff and makes it unnecessarily difficult. Terrible at offering clarification, often giving students attitude. She curves inconsistently, is inaccessible and would not offer additional practice when requested. Crazy and simply weird. Never again

absolute garbage. shes terrible. does not know how to speak clearly and literally sounds like the dumbest professor on the planet. I cannot emphasize this enough DO NOT TAKE HER CLASS. she will make you want to rip your hair out.

She is the worst professor I have ever had in my entire college life. Mumbles and impossible to understand. Breeze through the content just by reading herself and doesn't care if students follow up or not. It is supposed to be an introduction class for stat but made it a total disaster. Just never ever try to be in her class.

Beware if this is your first Stats course. Finished with an A after the curve, but only after an ungodly amount of time in office hours, reading the textbook. Maybe it was her first time teaching, but I was literally lost on day 1 thanks to her very hard-to-follow lectures.

Honestly, stay away from this professor with everything in your power. If you do not have a great grasp of statistics concepts before stepping foot in the door on day 1, you will be completely lost - if you do have a great grasp, prepare to be frustrated beyond belief as she talks in circles and overcomplicates lessons. Impossible to understand.

Nice professor and teaches the material well. She can be very easily accessed outside of class and is good at explaining there too. She wants you to succeed in the course so she is super helpful, and there is some grade adjustment at the end to help.

She was on maternity leave halfway through the semester (just before in-person classes were canceled), but she did a really good job teaching the material and offered help whenever she can. Content can be easy or hard depending on how you did on the previous stat courses. Overall, she's a kind and caring professor!

Professor Chkrebtii is great and is my favorite professor in the Statistics department. This was the first semester the class was offered so they were very lenient on grading. Professor Chkrebtii was very caring, explained concepts very well, and had a great and consistent notation system.

I have never done as well in a class in my entire college career. Chkrebtii is literally the best professor I have had so far on main campus. She is very logical and mathematical in how she thinks, and I can tell she's gotten a lot better at teaching with her mind, reading old reviews. Just know your basic calculus and algebra.

Dr. Chkrebtii was extremely kind and helpful, and she knew the material very well. However, I didnt always leave class understanding the material or the work we did in the examples. Overall though, she was always willing to help in office hours and graded easily.

Dr. Chkrebtii is a great choice for STAT 3201. The class is simple: 6 homeworks, 3 exams, and a group project. The exams are straightforward; the averages are high 80's, if they are below that she will curve the grade. You do need to study though. Her lectures are sometimes confusing, but she cares about her students and makes the exams reasonable.
Oksana is an amazing professor! Very clear, organized and inspirational. Would definitely recommend!

Very organized and clear. Exams are easy (averages around 90s/high 80s). Not a lot of homework (6 total the whole semester). Often makes minor but obvious mistakes during lecture but an overall great professor!
Oksana is a great professor. Her lectures (and handwriting!) are clear and enjoyable. She is kind, understanding, and knowledgeable. I look forward to taking her class again next semester.
She has no self-confidence and you will not satisfy with her lectures which are full of mistakes and unclear explanation therefore just read the book!

She is new at teaching and it's obvious: little class control, lacks confidence and clarity. She is nice and she tries her best  but spends too long on concepts yet doesn't explain them clearly. During the semester, 2 students in the class keep asking lots of questions (some of them were too irrelevant) and one student who  corrected  nearly everything she did. This was a little bit annoying.

She is not there for you certainly. I could get higher grade with half effort spent for that class. You can take her class if you want to do all hws, projects, midterms etc.  but at the end you are gonna take probably B and learn class material from the book.
Note to myself: do not take a class from inexperienced professors

Dr. Peruggia was a great instructor this past semester for Stat 4301! The course content is rather difficult for an undergrad course since it is statistical theory, but he is able to cohesively explain the concepts well. I liked the system of quizzes as they provided good practice for the exams. Difficult exams but the course was curved in the end.

The lecture note is not useful and hard to recognize what he writes. He doesn't give any sample practices before the exam review. only gives the range of sections. The tests were hard, the exam questions were related, and if you didn't figure out the first one, the rest of the questions could not solve.

The slides are disorganized and hard to read his handwriting. I took the first in person class after Covid and he probably had too high expectation on students. The exams are heavy with two midterms and one final, each with hard prove with few numbers and given little partial credits. He has few examples on slides. Consider not taking his class.

Yes, he has an accent and sometimes it was hard to make out what he was saying, but it seemed to me that the real problem is that Professor Peruggia failed to show that he was very interested in teaching.His priority was going through the required material on time but not necessarily explaining it.
His class is really disorganized. his italian accent could drive people crazy.
Mario is a great teacher. He explains things in good detail, and is relatively funny, too. His practice midterms are a pretty close to his actual midterms.

Fun teacher and very clear, though he has a thick Spanish accent.  He likes cats a lot.  Easy to follow along in class, almost the same thing every day.  If you follow along with notes, you will be fine.
Peruggia is a fantastic instructor.  He really knows his stuff, and gives a great lecture.  Do not expect to be spoon-fed.  He expects you to work as hard as he does.

I took Linder's Stats 2480 class online. If you just do his review packets before every midterm and understand you will do well in the class. The exams are the same as his reviews. Seems like a very nice guy who cares about his students and not a very hard class.

I've taken AP Statistics before so I was already familiar with 90% of the course materials. His lectures are probably the best ones I've had and I was able to understand and practice without having to look up or go through textbooks for additional guidance. His tests are manageable if you fully understand the course materials. He has humor as well!

I took his async class, he was an alright professor who provided a ton of material for help. If you do the homework and tophat you will understand the material. Daryl can be kinda boring and did not lecture the more difficult material as well. He is an alright professor, not bad, not great.

The class itself isn't bad; watch the lectures and fill in the blank slides with him and you'll be okay. The tests are fair contentwise, but they're very long and hard to finish on time unless you know what you're doing. His lectures are actually solid, but he spends a lot of time on easier material, and not enough on hard material.

Reading other reviews I guess that the online version of the class was not good but taking it in person this semester I really enjoyed it, Daryl is nice and funny and the in person classes had a lot of interaction with students despite being a class of 200 people (only 50-70) actually showing up usually. Study for tests and pay attention.

I had him when classes came back to in-person. He's an ok lecturer, but the class(which format he didn't write) feels really surface level and a waste of time. His tests are his own and he usually tested what he pointed to with TopHat questions. He did a good job trying to prepare us, there weren't any surprises and he let us use formula sheets.

This guy was bad. All of the classes were lectures recorded some year/s ago and were difficult to understand on top of taking up more time than one would be in class. Homework assignments were nothing like the tests. Tests are graded harshly and have more content than you can finish in the given time. He refuses to curve when averages are failing.

For an async class he provided a LOT of resources for studying/doing hws. Honestly an OK lecturer; Lectures are a hit or miss, either over-explaining or not explaining enough. Hws are disconnected from lectures (hes aware of this) and have limited attempts. Thankfully hes pretty responsive to emails. Hes not THAT bad but definitely not the best.

Professor is a super nice guy, but with all due respect, cannot teach to save his life. His lectures are a couple of years old, filled with mistakes. I recall one time he was explaining something and was like "This is because .... it just is what it is". The class is hard, just be prepared to study the practice exams a lot.
Online and had over 600 students so very independent class. Not helpful and not flexible. Does not reply to emails quickly and the overall course is not formatted well.

Lectures/lecture notes are outdated & not the best, but the book, office hours, and community make this class very manageable. He gives sample midterms/finals and keys that had (very) similar problems to the actual exams. He can be blunt with students but he ended up curving our class generously and really wasn't as bad as many made him out to be.

Uses pre-recorded lectures he recorded a couple of years ago. They're not very useful. Assigns homework and quizzes on WebAssign. Exams look nothing like homework and quizzes. Get ready to do a lot of self-teaching if you get this man as your prof.

Daryl seems like a very nice and likable guy, though he uses lectures that are several years old and have multiple mistakes and audio issues. Overall hes very approachable and kind, but his tests are very hard

Daryl is a horrid professor. His lectures, for some reason, are three years old and far longer than they need to be. Daryl does not care about your grade and makes that clear in his weekly videos where he talks about how the class is designed to have incredibly difficult midterms and a final being held up by homework and quizzes. Take 2470 at CSCC

Asynchronous class, but a really reasonable amount of work for a stats class. I had multiple weeks where I didn't have to do anything but study for exams. Daryl's office hours are awesome, but he can come off a little blunt/rude over email so would avoid that. If you do the work and stick to a schedule, it's not too bad at all.

If you watch the lectures and keep up with the work it is not bad. The quizes always have extra credit, and not a ton of homework. The lecture videos are also short and straight to the point. First midterm was easy, second was a lot harder but do-able.

Has zero lectures anduses recordings that are at least 2 years old. The recordings don't reflect the material in the homework. The homework doesn't reflect the material in the midterms/final. To his credit, he does hold weekly homework/exam study sessions that he attends Don't risk taking unless you are already very familiar with statistics.

Prepare to put your whole time in the semester to study for this class. The test questions are way harder than any practice problems given. His lectures are easy to understand but there are way more than if it is given in a in-person class. There are a lot of terms in the textbook that are different from his lecture beware. Class average not good.

Terrible class, but especially online. Lecture videos are several years old and the audio on them is terrible and they are longer than an actual in person class. This class is being offered in person next semester. So try that. It's probably done better in person than online.

He does not lecture, just posts videos that are several semesters old, full of mistakes, and have horrible audio quality. Lectures such that even if you are familiar with the content you will be lost. Exams are so far beyond the level of difficulty of the quizzes and the homework. Truly could not put in less effort, avoid if you want a good grade.

Daryl has good intentions but is unsuited for the online class. He doesn't do anything except post videos that are two years old. The lectures are nowhere close to the difficulty of the exams and they themselves are your entire grade. He seems nice, unfortunately you don't get too much interaction with him outside of office hours

Took him over summer. I hated his online structure. HW and Quizzes are useless. His exams were hard. Dont expect a curve because he curved only 1% plus. Try to study a lot and catch up if you want a good grade. At least he cares about his students like a lot of office hours, answering discussion board. Use those if you need help.

Probably fine in-person. Horrible online. Recorded lectures are not good, and exam problems were entirely different from anything practiced in lectures or on homework. I'd probably give him the benefit of the doubt for in-person stats, but online he seemed to put in the bare minimal amount of effort for the class.

Daryl wasn't the worst professor and clearly knew how to teach beginners but I hated how this class was structured online. Prerecorded lectures each week that are way longer than spending time in an actual class learning. Ch 6 was the only unit that was taught differently than what was on exams. He cares but puts no effort into teaching.

I took this class online over the summer, and I had a pretty good experience with it. I went to office hours once and posted on the discussion boards a few times when I was confused, and he responded quickly and explained things rather well. The structure of this class is lecture and homework heavy, but the exams are what to look out for.

Took him online and it wasn't my favorite. Daryl clearly shows that he's passionate about teaching stats to students and while you could get what he is trying to communicate, his video lectures do a poor job solidifying concepts. Also the exams were your only grade so goof one and your hopes of getting a good grade are done

I had an online class with all material recorded, and optional homework sessions but they were at a time that I had other classes, and his office hours were 8 am on a friday... I wish this class just had a dedicated time you could schedule. He had 500 students and no live lectures, of course this class sucks. He cares but doesn't put in the effort.

Dont take him for this class if you can. If you have to avoid the online section. The prerecorded lectures were terrible and barely explained anything well. Just some concepts with like only one example and thats it. No actual help from him other than what was minimally required from him. Exams were difficult but made worse online.

I'm sure these previous reviews regarding Daryl over the past few years are true to their core. However, with online learning Daryl is rather lazy. His lectures have no organized format and he provides no extra help other than what is needed. I took him for Stat 3470 SU21, and by far he is the worst professor I have ever had. I would not recommend.

Lectures can be long but are good resources for exams. The assignments in this course are fair as long as you practice the material and study for exams. It is easy to fall behind and get lost if you aren't on top of actually working through the homeworks and quizzes. Overall, Daryl was a good lecturer and provided a lot of notes and other material.

Great human being. Is a bit paranoid about tests and talking about them after you have taken them, but I think he may of had a bunch of students cheat in semesters prior so I get it. The subject is not easy. Id put it in hardest 10% of classes Ive taken as a CSE majorup there with 2421. 3470 as a whole likely sucks, Daryl is a good option for it.

Very few men on this planet carry an appreciation for statistics comparable to that of Daryl's. Lectures have their limits when some difficult topics are covered, but Daryl is more than willing to help. Homework is reasonable in frequency, but don't do it last minute. Exams are reasonable and study guides are plentiful. Start HW early.

You need to study hard for this class the exams are not hard as long as you do review the material and do the practice questions. I personally do not find the webassign hw useful. The class is set up to be very flexible, you only need to complete weekly hw and tophat and discussions are due before exams. Do not wait till last minute.

Daryl is a really nice guy, the class itself is just so hard for people who are thrown into it. Do the WebAssigns without googling them, make a review sheet before exams, and go to office hours and you will most definitely end up with a solid grade. He made the exams super hard though, but it weeds out those who studied and didn't.

Daryl is a very a tough grader and does not update grades throughout the semester so you go into each midterm not knowing your grade. Also said during one of his review sessions that he makes multiple choice hard on purpose to trick students. Would never take him again and would recommend not taking him.

Very frustrating teacher with unclear lectures. I took pass fail because of his lack information and it turns out there will be a large curve announced way past the pass/fail date. Would have nice for him to have said it earlier so students could make an educated decision. AVOID at all costs.

Disconnected lectures and exams. Video lectures don't explain concepts. Not enough practice problems. Doesn't use Carmen correctly. Syllabus doesn't have information needed (when assignments are due/exam dates).

His lectures are awful. The length is way longer than the time you would be in class if it were taught in person and there aren't enough examples to teach you the concepts in order to do well on the TopHat questions and homework. He also requires an absurd amount of work and overexplaining on his exams in order to even receive a B. Overall bad prof

I had him pre-Covid, and is by far one of my favorite instructors. He was enthusiastic when lecturing, he added humor to the top hat questions which were for participation, but I think you only had to get %50 of them correct to get the full points. He taught stats in high school, so he knows how to teach to beginners. Tests are pretty difficult

Absolute nightmare. Imagine putting on tophat questions you haven't even covered before and doesn't even explain how to do it. It's been like this the entire semester and I'm honestly just fed up. No effort done to transition things online at all.

Daryl's teaching for 3470 ranges from adequate to excellent. The class seems fair, and there are plenty of opportunities for practicing concepts, including homework problems, sample midterms, TopHat problems, textbook problems, and additional review problems. There's also a bunch of tutoring available. Only problem: strict grading on midterms.

Does close to no actual teaching. His lectures lack concrete examples and he rarely ever explains the variables he uses. Exams poorly reflect content from homework and quizzes. Terrible professor, perhaps it is because the class is online this semester, but he has not adjusted at all.
Prerecorded lectures that are below average at best. Barely gives examples and doesn't provide reasoning. Get ready to learn it on your own.
